div.p: Can the archives of an email list be stored in TEI? This seems like a reasonable question, to which the answer, especially with the new Computer-mediated Communcation chapter of the TEI Guidelines, should be a simple yes.

In order to prove this, each co-author attempted to encode a subset of the archives of TEI-L, the main email discussion list for TEI, in TEI. While our methods were wildly different, our conclusions are similar: the answer is yes, but it is a lot harder than you might expect.

div.p: Our initial thought was that converting the data to XML would be easy, and that most of our attention would be directed towards the more interesting part of deciding exactly how to encode it in TEI. However, it turns out that both parts were problematic — it was very difficult to convert the data into XML, and in several cases there is no TEI encoding that is really satisfactory.

Our two approaches were
an automated conversion of mass data to a basic TEI representation for archiving and potential later enhancement
a craft encoding of a short range of months or years worth of posts

div.head: Mass conversion approach
div.p: Our goal for the mass conversion approach was to convert all of TEI-L from its inception up to 2024-04-29. That end date was chosen because it was the day the mailing list was moved from Brown University’s LISTSERV to Penn State University’s LISTSERV. Thus we were able to obtain the entire dataset directly from Brown listmaster without needing to worry about merging in data from PSU or about posts made just after we obtained the data. The Brown listmaster sent us 412 separate files, one for each month, i.e., tei-l.log9001 through tei-l.log2404.
Step 1 was thus to rename the log files to use 4-digit (as opposed to 2-digit) years so that they sorted into the correct order.

div.head: Illegal characters (for XML)
div.p: Early e-mail systems used ASCII (7-bit) characters only. Thus there were 128 available code points (0–2⁷-1, or 0–127). Of those 128 available code points, only 99 of them are legal XML characters. The remaining 29 characters (for which see ) are all non-printing control characters, intended for controlling the behavior of a peripheral device such as a paper tape or printer, or (in a few cases) whitespace. While neither of us is an expert on early e-mail systems, we suspect that the designers never intended these characters to be used in e-mail, but did not feel it necessary to do anything to prevent them from being used, as the average user of a computer had no way of generating them.

However, of the 29 characters that are not legal in XML, 17 of them occur in the TEI-L archives:
64 occurrences in 34 posts before 2000 (which not surprising)
38 occurrences in 11 posts after 2008 (which we did not expect)
These characters were generally used to not to represent the control characters to which they are mapped in the ASCII character set, but rather to represent various accented characters that were not part of the original (7-bit) ASCII set. The last use of a character that is illegal in XML was on 2016-03-13.
